job_title: Associate Supply Chain Analyst in Orlando, FL
pros: Flexible work arrangements, good healthcare, business is growing and stable, lots of room from growth (at least in supply chain). Some people work extra on Fridays, but you typically won't have for work past 3PM Fridays. I currently have a great work life balance in the entry level position. My department is instituting a program to get us profession training in leadership, automation, and other useful softwares/ programs. (Please note this is not company wide)
cons: The PTO systems and culture around PTO is odd. You do not get paid holidays, you must use your PTO bank. The company has a list of observed holidays, and I have heard people say they work them so they can get work done and be left alone. It was a red flag for me. I have been here almost 6 months now, and my manager always approves my time off, but using PTO just feels weird here. If you don't mind some of the weirder aspects of how Advent sets up benefits, its a great company to work for.

pros: 1. Compelling mission statement where "living God's love" is more than just a catchphrase. You are treated with love and respect. 2. The culture is one that is filled with supportive individuals who will focus on your growth and success. 3. Compensation and benefits are competitive. 4. They care about your well-being and highly encourage you to take the weekends off and take time with your family. They walk the walk.
cons: 1. Current, post-pandemic strategy is somewhat unclear. New leadership has focused primarily on minimizing shared services and placed emphasis on market hospitals and clinics being responsible for many areas. 2. Compensation increases are fixed and are often not based on performance, but rather are based on tenure. 3. Many rounds of recent layoffs have eroded some of the previous cultural strengths and there is a sense of worry and confusion from lack of clear communication.

pros: Fair market compensation, annual cost of living increases (though, I have not seen this yet), clearly-defined roles, scheduling accommodations for school (have to let them know well ahead of time), friendly and approachable management, good in-house benefits, fun, friendly and compassionate staff, varied clientele (though there is a cohort of "frequent fliers"), a number of opportunities for advancement via clinical ladder, options to cross-train in other specialties/departments, recent magnet status. hospital promotes good values and work ethic. clean and professional environment. good IT support. solid pharmacy support and always available. modern electronic equipment. excellent support from security team for codes.
cons: It was hard to pick up extra shifts in psych due to all the new hires, but at least they were adequately staffed. (if you have med surge or ICU experience there are plenty of shifts to pick up). sometimes the census is low and your shift can get canceled. Their benefits and apps page is pretty clunky and takes some getting used to but I suppose it's not unusual. Very little interprofessional collaboration between nursing and social work, bordering on antagonistic at times. Some of the MDs and PsyDs do not consult with staff nurses and can come off as arrogant and disconnected. The Behavioral Health program director is a nice man but is generally aloof.

pros: I like working for Adventist Health because I get to work in my strengths. My staff and leaders care about me as a person. I feel supported to not only do my job but to grow into my next job.
cons: At this time, I do not have any negative feedback.

pros: Co-workers are great to work with
cons: Corporate leadership is a good old boys network of mostly white men who give lip service to “mission” but really only care about the money. They are constantly restructuring the organization and losing their best people. Your personal connections to senior leadership and how Adventist you are are more important than your skills or experience. They don’t really care about employees, you are an expendable expense. Mismanagement led to the risk of the company losing its “A” bond rating in 2022 and caused panic and mass layoffs. Meanwhile, the company remained committed to building a multi million dollar wellness facility in Florida, completely across the country from its service area on the West Coast - and AFTER the Florida-based Advent Health had declined the opportunity. Makes 0 business sense. They waste significant meeting time in lengthy religious devotionals and pressure you to attend scores of meetings instead of letting everyone be productive.

great benefits

The salary is not as high as sorrounding hospitals. pros: You will get great work experience that will advance your career once you leave.
cons:
Unless you have ties to the church, don't bother trying to have any management or upper management position.  Moral seems to be at an all-time low across the board.  It’s hard watching unqualified individuals get huge pay bumps and quick advancements because they or their family is affiliated with the Adventist Church.  There is a HUGE disconnect between the corporate office and the sites.  
Pay is below average for most workers. You will have carrot dangled in front of you for years.  After meeting or beating every expectation, you are given excuses about how your raise or desired position is not in the budget.  Meanwhile, management is getting HUGE pay bumps and bonuses.  Management getting pay bumps wouldn’t be such an issue, if they weren’t in spite of their many failures. 
 If you are part of the “in crowd”, mistakes don’t matter.  Neither do job requirements.  There are a number of persons, with management titles, that don’t have degrees.  If you are not in that crowd, they want advanced degrees, certifications, and years of experience.   At half the pay…

pros: Good co-workers despite unfortunate working circumstances. Company supplies 3 sets of uniforms per year for FTE. Health insurance is offered but expensive. Free parking on-site. cons: Management does not care about employees, just concerned about making themselves look good. ICU is a poorly run circus due to bad management.  Not equipped to deal with tasks due to lack of resources, but upper management looks the other way. No affirmation for a job well done, just looking to place blame on bedside staff. Staff not paid fair market value for their skills, the hospital across the street pays much better and has better employee morale. Always running a bare bones staff... especially on weekends, comes as a safety risk for patients and employees. No critical care differential for ICU or ER staff, no weekend differential.

job_title: Patient Care Coordinator in Oakhurst, CA
pros:
A mission statement I could get behind and support.
(In my location) providing a needed service to members of my community.
Structure of employees is solid, with a sincere intention of thorough training.
cons:
My particular location was too busy to have the time to train me.  Training was glossed over and then I was expected to keep up with the other employees that had been there for years, which, of course, I was unable to.  The office manager at this location was impatient and unreasonable in her expectations.

Adventist Health, as a whole, intended to provide thorough training, but I felt that  so much of the training was lacking in some areas and unreasonably overwhelming and unrealistic in other ways.  The orientation training was a waste of time.  The job-specific, technical training started out promising, but there was just too much information to cover.  An unconscionable amount of information to learn.  By the end of the training, we were just inputting the proper codes into our "portals" so that we had them to use when we returned to the job - with no explanation as to what the codes were supposed represent or how we were to use them.

pros: work independently, develop your own schedule for the day based on your caseload. Time off. some good caring staff. Able to help families and advocate for them.
cons: social work supervisor plays favorites. there is one psychiatrist that keeps medical patients there for the full 14 day hold even if they are stabilized so he can continue to bill medical and get paid more money. The hospital is aware of this. There are also particular staff who play patient favorites on the adolescent unit, are punitive with patients they don't like. The hospital is aware of this. Hospital falsifies documentation in patient charts if they know JAICO  or the state is coming. Criticize employee that has a disability and not sensitive to their needs.

pros: There are some good people who work here. Good work/life balance for those managers who practice and support it.
cons:
Favoritism, nepotism, cronyism—oh no! Experience, talent and skill are less important than being Seventh-day Adventist or a friend of someone with power and influence. The company’s nepotism is rampant: sons, daughters, husbands, wives, nieces, nephews, aunts, uncles, in-laws, out-laws, second cousins thrice removed, etc. 

Adventist Health is a hierarchical organization. Translation: If you’re asked to do something that makes no sense, just do it. Don’t ask why. Don’t bother to recommend a different approach. This is unfortunate as there are smart, motivated employees who could make a difference if given the opportunity. Most move on. 

While there is a lot of talk about innovation, the company is behind the curve. One example: the company is moving to open workspaces. Wow! Now that’s innovative! Except that high-tech firms in Silicon Valley pioneered the model in the 1990s and research shows that open workspaces reduce productivity and job satisfaction, and, gulp, even harm our health. Advice to Adventist Health leaders: Google the 2014 Forbes article, “Why the Open-Concept Office Trend Needs to Die.” Or Inc. magazine’s 2017 story, “Open-Plan Offices Kill Productivity, According to Science.”

Actually, the truth is, the leaders don’t need to Google any article. They just need to listen to their employees. If they did, the employee engagement they’re after would be easy to achieve. 

There are some wonderful people working at this company. Unfortunately, favoritism and a management style that discourages constructive dissent have undermined morale and created a toxic workplace.

job_title: Certified Nursing Assistant in Glendale, CA
pros: There were quarterly performance review with chance for slight pay raise and adjustments. However it still doesn't equate to the heavy workload we had. During my year there I had up to 24 patients to myself at a time during busy day shift due to being short staffed. I complained multiple times and found out after I left the load decreased to 14 a person which is much much safer and more doable to provide quality care. I will always remember the passionate nurses who work so hard and care for their patients and make work more enjoyable during bad days. They work to please patients, provide quality care, and collaborate with the doctor for great care. Plus, this is THE PLACE to go to get a lot of experience in a short amount of time. The nurses and nursing staff are very overworked and expected to do a lot. From what I hear,  all the nurses and nursing staff that came quit after GAMC have great work ethic and skills so that their next job will be a a lot easier and very manageable.
cons: Very high turnover rate. During the year I was there, 10+ CNAs quit due to the difficult load, non proportional pay, and non supportive management. However management is also pressured from higher up so it's not entirely manager fault.

review_title: Beneath the surface propaganda, they are all about the Benjamins.
pros: The pay and benefits were better than most companies in the area for this type of work.
cons: This company absolutely does not have your back.  I was assaulted by a patient in the ED after responding to call for help after the patient had already physically assaulted two of the nursing staff.  The ensuing physical confrontation between him and I resulted in injuries to myself.  I was initially flat-out denied my rights under workman's compensation by Employee Health.  I was told to use my own sick and vacation time to recover from my injuries and blamed for getting my injuries. I was treated rudely and disrespectfully by an employee with a reputation for such behavior.  The persons job apparently is to bully and intimidate employees to not take time off, with seemingly the company's full knowledge and blessing.  Only because of bodily fluid exposure was I finally granted help under worker's comp.  Apparently, the risk of a lawsuit against them was too high to continue to screw me over.  Turn-over of staff is high.  Middle management run around like scared rabbits afraid to make any waves with upper management for fear of getting fired, legitimately so.  Upper management is inaccessible and uncaring to life in the trenches.   If nothing else, its a job until you can find someplace better to work at.

review_title: Less than desirable coding practices and Management is sub-par
job_title: Certified Professional Coder in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Great Benefits.  Pay is decent.
cons: Coding is all about pushing out as many charts as possible.  Definite quantity over quality mindset.  Supervisor does not allow collaboration and wants to be head bull, treating coders as "lesser than".  I was asked on numerous occasions to put 100+ charts on the "non-productive" hours which brings your numbers down.  If you don't actually change a code you can't count that chart even though you reviewed and even emailed your supervisor regarding them which took days to get answers to questions.  Remote positions are anything but flexible.  Good luck if you have ADA/FMLA accommodations as they will not work with you and may find any way to get rid of you once requested.  I wish I could say anything good but I can't, other than I am glad to be working elsewhere and being appreciated for my knowledge and experience.

review_title: Great place to start out or retire...
pros: Friendly environment and great healthcare. The doctors and nurses are absolutely amazing! It's good learning environment if it's you're first introduction to a big corporate healthcare system.
cons: They do the Catholic shuffle with people who should, in fact, be fired and the Peter principle reigns supreme. A change of the old guard is desperately, desperately needed. GAMC could be a great place if fresh blood was brought in at the leadership level however, they have a "We've always done it this way" attitude so nothing will change. Not the best place to work to be honest. They don't offer competitive wages, and they ask a person to tolerate a lot of dysfunction by not doing anything about issues that are present or brought to the forefront. If you're just graduating from school, looking for a stepping stone kind of place, or you know you're  going to retire in 5-10 years and you just want to collect a paycheck- this is your place.

pros: Great pay, benefits, supportive, friendly and helpful staff and charge nurses/unit manager. The hospital has a snack cart with coffee and various food items (sandwiches, chips, salads, fruit, cookies, coffee, etc, that make rounds to the units several times a day for those nurses who are unable to go to the cafeteria for their break.
cons: The size of the ICU, eight beds, made census a potential problem. Nurses are on a rotation, If the census is low staffing will either call you off or put you on call for the first four hours and when they call in four hours you're either put on call the rest of the shift, called in, or staying home. Nice for when one is looking for time off, bad when you need pay.

pros: Employees are treated well for the most part.  Good benefits, average salaries, and - if you make it there long enough - excellent PTO accrual.
cons: In my opinion, the amount of middle management bloat is mind boggling - we’re talking three to four layers of red tape before you get to anyone who is actually willing to make a decision.  There is very little that teams of employees can do to get bad managers out of the system.  Change management is non-existent.  Over the last six years, corporate leadership consolidated and/or outsourced most of the following departments: Facilities, HR, Finance, Biomed/HTM, IT, and Accounting.  Corporate and site specific leadership turnover (and provider turnover for that matter) is high.  Wage inequality, in my opinion, is alive and well in this company.

pros: I worked at Glendale Adventist Medical Center. The workload, staff, and patients were great. Hospital is beautiful and patient care comes first. Pay is ok.
cons:
I am not sure if the hospital is in a strong financial bind, but I began to notice that it started to strongly feel that way. Hours began to be extremely budgeted and put under a microscope. There is no standby pay, nor any differential for being on-call on weekends. Along side that, one of the main patient elevators has been out of order for over 6 months, making it inconvenient for patients, maybe they do not want to pay to fix it? 

When I left, a new manager started to oversee the department. She was really nice, however she was a one person show overseeing employees, answering calls, handling authorizations and referrals, scheduling patients, and doing paperwork. Unfortunately micromanaging was becoming a huge issue. Some type of administrative assistant is desperately needed in this department to alleviate the heavy load.

review_title: Very flexible schedule, but not good for anyone looking for steady hours
pros: Flexible working with students and people with other jobs, good benefits if you can get enough hours to attain them.
cons: Cannot depend on getting the hours you need, better to expect getting paid less than you need. When other companies come in to do surveys on the hospital, everyone is extremely emotional and snappish. You can meet both amazing people and horrible people, in terms of employees. The patients are normally very sweet, thats the best part of the job. If you're looking to go up, this is the wrong job, most people who cant stand the job are there going up 10-15 years, unlikely you'll get the position.

pros:
Freedom to express yourself spiritually.
Believing in the mission statement.
Great opportunity for training if you're a new nurse.
cons:
Active bully culture.
Not much room for growth.

review_title: Not a great experience at all
pros: Didn't experience too many pros working there, benefits were decent if you went only within the Adventist Health network, good 401k match. If you work up in Corporate in Roseville, then your work environment is gorgeous and you seemed to get more of the company culture and perks.
cons: Personally, I absolutely did not experience any of the "mission-driven compassion" they're really striving for. Maybe I fell beneath the cracks during the whole business transformation, because other people seemed to be happy-ish working there, but the whole "we're going through a business transformation" excuse really seemed like a bunch of BS to not really care about their employees. My directors absolutely did not care about me as a person, and my mental and physical health deteriorated tremendously while I worked there. No formal training and completely disorganized onboarding. Pay scale is low for recruiters in comparison to other hospitals.

job_title: Certified Nursing Assistant in Saint Helena, CA
pros: Positive work environment, great coworkers who are generally supportive of each other, good benefits, flexible schedule, beautiful Napa valley views from the hospital,
cons: Management is sometimes impersonal with staff and provide poor feedback on performance for raises; the pay could be better considering the cost of living around the hospital is very expensive, many employees commute from 45min to over an hour away

review_title: This company is so good that the pay breaks my heart
pros: I love Adventist Health as an organization. They truly stand by their mission for their community, and they hire some of the best people. My coworkers are amazing, and the facility is decent. Management is verbally supportive, and you actually see them regularly, unlike other hospitals.
cons: The pay is so low that you can only afford to live in the area comfortably if you rent a studio, and tightly if you rent a 1br. This doesn't work so great if you have to support even 1 other person. Shouldn't have to commute >1hr each way just because you have children.

pros: There are a few amazing people that work at this organization.  And by few I mean five.
cons: Horrible upper management. No direction.  Treated unfairly not only due to not being of Adventist Faith but for also being one of the only non white employees. If you do not kiss some serious butt of upper management - ( plan nacho days , birthday celebrations, or assist with every single social event) you will not be considered a good employee. For two years I had to deal with a certain member of upper management who would walk by my cube every morning without smiling, or even acknowledging my presence. Your work will not be appreciated or considered  unless you win " most smiley" .  This place needs to realize and appreciate DIVERSITY.  Upper management is a joke. If you are involved or affiliated with the church you will have job security. Regardless of your work ethic .

review_title: Good Company in the Heart of Los Angeles
job_title: Anonymous Employee in East Los Angeles, CA
pros: Great environment to work in. Most of the employees are nice and there is a sense of "family" among everyone. Decent medical benefit and generous PTO. Since it's an Seventh Day Adventist hospital, most administrative departments are let out early on Friday. Free parking which is a big deal if you're working so close to DTLA. Metro Gold Line station is right behind hospital so it's easy for those who take the commuter train. Company really tries its best to make its employees happy.
cons: It is a non-profit organization so there is all the negative aspects that comes with working with a limited budget. Also, it is a Christian-faith based hospital so it is more conservative than what we are use to in Los Angeles, or at start-ups. It has never been a problem for me though. Company doesn't try to shove their conservative views down your throat or anything.

review_title: Lack of proper leadership  falls this place. Unfair Management with no history or training
pros: good insurance, clean grounds, bright with natural light in most waiting rooms
cons: Stressful place to work for staff and Doctors caused by management. Lower management are sneaks in the grass, middle management provides no support the newer employees, the promote from within without posting the position and the people they promote because of seniority not education and ablity. My experience: The longer you've been employeed the more believable your lie is. I  work with a smile all day long, keep patients happy, working with quality and pride to only be blacked balled by the coworkers that are cheating the clock. The sadiest thing, the Director turns a blind eye and a deft ear to valid complaints.

review_title: Great place to work if you are Adventist "Royalty" not so much for everyone else.
pros: Adventist has a good overall compensation package and like any other healthcare organization they have good health benefits.  Some managers are very understanding regarding PTO.
cons: Lack of leadership is a systemic problem at Adventist Health.  Senior management constantly bad mouths each other in front of staff.  Also, if you are Adventist you will have opportunities that non-Adventist do not have.  I was in an interview when one Adventist employee said to an Adventist job candidate that he would have more opportunities just because he was Adventist.  I cannot tell you the number of times that I have witnessed an Adventist "Prince" or "Princess" screw up with no consequences.

job_title: RN Staff Nurse in Portland, OR
pros: I enjoyed most of my co workers.
cons: Management takes care if themselves and the cuts come out of the little guy. The incentive is gone the insurance premium's go up, and the plan with the most coverage that's the cheapest you have to jump through hoops for. Management gets way better coverage and plans and perks and bonus's! The RNs and aids and all others take cuts and pay more! Terrible staff to pt. Ratio too. Non union. Poor amount of raises.

pros: Work/Life balance is great! We get out at 3:30 on Fridays and work is so easy.
cons: Its so boring and people seam so fake like if they are in a totally different bubble. An Adventist Bubble. Its who you know I guess. No real chance of growth and leadership plays favorites. Not using staff to their potential because the older execs are set in their ways and things move like molasses.

review_title: Terrible Company Wrapped in Supposed "Christian" Values and Morals
pros:
- Some coworkers are very nice and friendly 
- Free coffee if you drink them
- Nice new building (open office is a no-no though)
- Inspiring worship talks
cons:
You can't pay me enough to even step foot in their door. I left my job of almost 9 years with promises of "better opportunity" and "we will equip you for success" only to realize that they were all lies.

My manager who was also new was always out to get me in trouble and wrote up lies about me on paper to HR department who forced me to sign the papers. I was given hardly any training, my trainer complained about my "asking too much questions" as she comes late everyday, then goes and have breakfasts, and then talks to her friends for hours and yet I'm the bad person? 

Worst decision of my life moving to a company whose supposed mission was "Living God's Love" because there is zero of Christianity and values in this company.  Never again....

pros: The first three months everyone's nice and great. Daily inspirational emails at 8 am. Coffee machine is awesome. Friday worship is great.
cons: The honey moon is over just when you think you've landed a great job you realize your once sweet boss is cycling in her bipolar manic way. She tells you it's hard to believe in God and struggles daily with it. Then you realize why she went through 14 temps in 5 months. Temps are off the books and not part of HR and she knows it. Therefore she treats them like second class citizens after a month.

job_title: Applications Support Analyst in Roseville, CA
pros:
Mission

Good people (for most part)

Great environment

Feel like my work makes a difference

Learning everyday

Feel like my work is appreciated
cons:
Certain rules, expectations don't apply to everyone.

The environment/culture changes drastically depending on your director. 

Company does not have the same "great place to work" feel/attitude as when I first started, which is unfortunate because this is what keeps people here.

Pay is well below what other health networks pay their IT employees.

review_title: Over worked and under valued. When asked to go perm they dropped Pay $11 an hr.
pros: Lots of overtime, guaranteed work, hardly ever sent home due to lack of work. Lots of call if you like Call and working weekends
cons: My first night of Call I had worked full shift. Came in for additional 7 hrs. The following Saturday again on Call. Called in for additional 12 hrs. Last minute add on exams were the norm at the end of my shift. Then talked to about doing exams faster to cut my overtime. Because it was hurting the budget!?

pros: The faith based culture allows for practice of faith in facility. You are allowed to pray with patients, staff and start meetings that way.
cons:
The top down leadership. They continue to speak about transparency but there is none. They are focusing on the wrong things like cutting the budget by cutting the staff which will result in lowering the quality of care, tons of research has shown this to be true. 
Also, they can't decide what is priority: brining in Studer to improve employee engagement and HCAHPS but making budget cuts at the same time and pressuring staff to work short staffed. These things do not go hand in hand, they actually contradict each other.

pros: There are a lot of good and passionate people working for Adventist Health.  The faith based culture is prominent and meaningful to many.  Nice working environment overall
cons: Senior leadership is very poor, and primarily reserved for members of the 7th Day Adventist Church, so advancement opportunities if you are not Adventist are virtually impossible.  Many of the Senior Leaders are children of other Senior Leaders from sister hospitals and are not qualified.

pros:
Team :Leads (managers) assign projects and allow you to work them- very little micromanagement; great sense of community; maintaining a healthy life is important and promoted; although associated with the Adventist church, their beliefs are not pushed upon you.
Resources needed to complete tasks are plentiful.
cons: Although management's ability to make you feel like your services are beneficial to the company, yearly reviews and pay structure are in need or rework.  Yearly evaluations are broken down to several factors and are rated in several quartiles- bad to extremely well.  Although I continue to excel in my duties and receive highest marks on reviews, I tend to receive merely a $.75/per hour raise, which is a similar pay raise to those assigned and performing at a sub-par levels of work.   Also, your ability to promote within the company has less to do with your performance and more to do with your ability to network with management.  Because of this, a lot of the work assigned to those in a higher position gets taken away and reassigned to those in lower ranking positions, which also has a lot to do with the high turnover rate seen at AH.

review_title: There are many opportunities for improvement at Adventist Health.
pros: I am supportive of the mission of the hospitals, but struggle with balancing the mission with making ends meet.
cons: Not a lot really, other than politics.  They are not willing to risk trying a better way of doing things.  Policy does not allow it.  Some managers are so focused on maintaining policy, they can't see the opportunities.

review_title: Outpaitent operation overview for souther california
job_title: Director of Operations in Los Angeles, CA
pros:
Good benefits if you're single.
Large company
People in the organization care
Roseville corporate leadership understands the business side more than the regional leadership
work life balance.  Job was easy because there is no accountability
Corporate office support was great (Roseville).
cons:
To many layers of management.
Micro management from president of medical services network
Lack of accountability
No clear vision.  Worked there 2 years and I had no idea what our strategic plan was.
Mission not aligned with actions

job_title: RN Care Manager in Hanford, CA
pros: Great benefits (full time, can get medical insurance around $44/month for self), great PTO amount, and it increases the longer you are there. Great pay, and pay increases yearly in July, plus market value pay increases. Best to start in May or June, so you can get the yearly wage increase in the next July. I started in Sep, and had to wait 1 year and 10 months
cons:
See above if you are hired shortly after July, the yearly wage increases are only done in July. 
Schedule may or may not be flexible. Floor RNs have a set schedule for a year. As Care Manager case loads can be difficult and heavy. This area has a lot of social problem patients (homeless, drug users, patients dumped by families) and not as many resources.

review_title: Cult like atmosphere and behavior- management is the worst I have ever worked for
job_title: Registered Nurse in Saint Helena, CA
pros: Loved the area, fellow employees/physicians were fun to work with, great clients/patients
cons: Evil management, many employees with no experience or with suspended/restricted nursing licenses hired to cut costs. Serious bullying which is encouraged by management. No privacy--my ICU manager ( who has zero management qualifications and has been fired in the past for HIPAA violations, ironically) forwarded emails of employees personal information to fellow staff without permission nor need. Absolutely no incentive to stay--poor pay, no ability to advance. Several, several safety issues with patient care that were covered up by formulated lies placed in employees charts, several well hidden legal issues (performing unnecessary procedures, falsifying employee and patient records, complaints to the joint commission, complaints to several labor boards...etc,etc,etc...). This place will pay off or deceive anybody to keep them quiet, since the hospital relies on donor support.

pros: The pharmacist team are wonderful.  Most of them are very supportive and help you get trained.
cons: During the orientation process they make a point to tell us they want only happy people around, but the manager keeps and makes excuses for some pharmacists who are not happy to be there.   Telepharmacists are stuck between manager who wants perfection, but onsite managers who tell there team to snitch on every single mistake made.  Sometimes it feels like we are walking on egg shells and get called out for issues that are not big of a deal.

review_title: for experience or to start, yes but if your looking for a career or making money then don't waste your time
pros: Management will work very hard on getting you coverage when needed
cons: the work load is too much. No 10 min breaks and sometimes no lunch coverage. When you ask for help and you get we will try as an answer. Providers don't even get a lunch break most of the time. The pay is not that great for this type of situation

pros: Pays is in line with the market, friendly environment, and the company is growing.
cons: Benefits are well below other health care companies. Especially health plan and vacation especially. Work load is above normal for several work groups, creating little to no work life balance, claims to be data driven but frequently ignores data to make decisions management wants. Being well liked more important than being good at your job. Nepotism and cronyism have lead to management with little understanding of how to run a health care organization.

job_title: Telemetry Tech in Saint Helena, CA
pros: Great Co-workers and patients. Loved who I worked with and what I did. I enjoyed working with almost everyone in the hospital. It was like a big family.
cons: BAD management in the ICU. Lies constantly to get what she wants. Hires unqualified employees to cut costs. Has no care for the team. Shares personal information with fellow employees. We lost So many very qualified wonderful nurses because her lack of care for the staff. Definitely a lot of favoritism in the scheduling and hiring. I would have never left if it wasn't for her.

pros: I cannot add any pros.
cons: Interview was haphazard. Two people failed to show up for work. I waited for over thirty minutes. Then was handed off to staff who conducted the interview while the manager listened. The manager was too busy ordering baked goods on the phone to participate in the interview. At the end of the interview, I was told that they'd call me in a week. They didn't. After ten days, I called the HR number, explained I was waiting for a call. She had the tone Well, they never called, figure it out, sweetie. She stated she'd pass my information on and the recruiting team would email me with updates. Four days later, no email. I'd say definitely skip them. Look elsewhere ifthis is how they treat and educated and licensed professional.

job_title: Psychiatric Social Worker in Portland, OR
pros: Opportunity to help patients with acute psychiatric and medical needs in a small hospital.
cons: Hospital management fosters a culture that excludes Latinos and people of color, unless they push a mop, or, change bed pans, and openly disparages Spanish Language Speakers and immigrants of different cultures. Their culture of exclusion protects employees who are members of their church despite their openly hostile and unwelcoming behaviors toward employees of different cultures who are not members of their sectarian community.

job_title: Monitor Tech/Unit Secretary in Rocklin, CA
pros: Fabulous atmosphere with positive staff. Co-workers are more family than staff.
cons: This is a non-profit Hospital therefore wages are lower than competition scales. The Christian foundation is worth the sacrifice

pros: Pay, benefits, engagement with leaders events, and decent food.
cons:
* Below-average phone etiquette from various departments, sometimes immediately when the conversation starts.
* Certain department supervisors do not have the best interests of their own departments in mind.
* Questionable competence of certain staff members, especially pharmacy and nursing, made me worry about patient safety and patient care on a regular basis.

pros: Faith based organization - if you are into that kind of thing.   Low turnover rate. Good work environment.  Well integrated.
cons:
Being stable and with very little turnover, it can be difficult to advance in career. Advancement may also be limited to people of faith. As with all hospital organizations, the work is very complex.   
One issue is that they have 'forced vacation days' where they ask you to take an extra day off when there is a holiday.  -But this cuts into your stored vacation and makes it hard to save up enough for a week or two vacation.

review_title: Management is completely incompetent. Working within the Admitting department was the worst experience ever.
job_title: Emergency Room Admitting in Glendale, CA
pros: The one pro this place had was that we had 12 hour shifts while working in the Emergency Room. Therefore, you would only have to work 3 days a week.
cons: The business management sector of this hospital lacked professionalism, was untrustworthy, and had no appreciation or respect for their employees. Only those who were either close friends or relatives of those in management were considered for open positions/ promotions.

pros:
Worship on Friday mornings
Cares about the health of patients and employees 
Does fun things for employees to raise money for charity
cons:
Loyalty is not recognized. 
New ideas are frowned upon

review_title: Old-fashioned, extremely vertical structure, broken systems, ineffective leadership = unhealthy workplace
pros:
* Great mission
* Sweet treats served regularly (also a Con)
* Changes planned for a few years down the road
* Fair pay (if you stick to hours assigned, and don't "volunteer" your life away to meet work goals)
cons:
* Vertical company that leads from the top without trust in their hires -- no delegation or authority shared
* Outdated, old fashioned structure and management
* Style and culture backward, a few decades. Things you take for granted now days are not there
* All systems broken. Currently working to get  new systems, but extremely slow and uninformed
* High demand for output without reality-check. Employees cannot achieve goals with resources provided but are still held accountable for them. 
* Hiring is based on who knows who, and often based solely on shared faith group, not talent, experience, education
* Ridiculous rules that have nothing to do with job requirements, such as menial tasks unrelated to job.
* High-level managers allowed to use poor management with little oversight or guidance. Most have not had prior experience other than within the company. They base decisions on narrow experience without education or knowledge of better methods
* Insufficient training for managers and positions
* Broken trust shown in all areas and levels of management. They do not keep their word. They do not provide support for employees. They do not genuinely listen or take advisor e to heart. They do not consider employee input valuable. They pay heed only to higher management, who do not get around  to learn what is happening beneath them.
* Management makes no effort to meet employees and know them. 
* Management allows bullies in the workplace.  They do not investigate complaints or take any action to resolve issues.

review_title: Ridiculously Backward Community Hospital, possibly racist
pros: A Paycheck, average to above industry standard for compensation based on location
cons: Use of a very old and unpopular electronic health record software (Cerner), lots of gossip at the nursing station, use of paper and even masking tape to communicate health care information, outdated equipment, old and uncomfortable beds that patients complain about, lack of diversity among staff members (especially in management and administration).

review_title: Do you really want to work for Feather River Hospital?
pros: A quiet and rural setting that is located in the foothills of the sierra nevada mt range. The location cuts down on a lot of the big city problems.
cons: Lack of professional growth or development. Senior leadership has been in control for a significant period of time and is not up to date with the current trends in health care.

pros: Christian environment, good benefits, pay fair and inline with local market, family oriented. Nice work environment, fun group to work with!
cons: Senior leadership while solid & dedicated, stay too long in their roles and become stale, lack vision, excitement, forward thinking, and they do not "mingle" with the front line staff on any kind of regular basis. Turnover is quite high.

pros: Good employees who express care, compassion and exemplified the mission statement of the hospital
cons: Poor management. They do not care about employees concerns and are more concerned about making the hospital money. Increased safety concerns, heavy new nurse burnout which makes for high employee turnover. Continued failing Gallup polls the last 4 years yet none of the employees dissatisfaction is addressed

pros: Great fellow employees.  They've put a lot of money into improving the look of the hospital, which helps to make it a bit more pleasant to work in.
cons: Poorly managed from top to bottom.  Upper management gets its info from middle management who fails to support their employees and cares only about making themselves look good and promoting those whom they like on a personal level rather then those who are able to do the job best.

job_title: Senior Administrative Assistant in Roseville, CA
pros: Competitive pay (for most roles), Mission, making a difference in the community, co-workers, sense of doing good
cons: Questionable ethics. Lack of transparency and communication. Disparity and unequal treatment/discipline and rewards of/for staff,  no real incentive or recognition programs, PTO has to be used for holidays, top heavy, nepotism, favoritism, leadership do not "walk the talk", work/life balance is practiced most by those who can afford it. Shocking lack of documented practices, procedures and training.

pros:
Great place for new nurses to start up. 
Has some great nurses that are very helpful. 
Decent pay for Selma with yearly 2 percent increase.
cons:
Attending stafff meeting can be hard sometimes. Its mandatory. Once per month. 
Annual bonus is only $50, can be better. 
HR loses employee paperworks , they lost my retirement paperwork, which I found out a year later, and my submitted bachelor degree, which I submitted before I start my job.
Low census, nurses can get out on call pretty frequently.

pros: There are workers who are for you and treat you as if you are part of their family, team player.
cons: There and workers who can stab you in the back, such as directors, supervisors/coworkers, especially when you're out on family emergency leave to aid your ailing loved ones, that is my dad. Be care ful, file it carefully, always verify if your leave was approved. Poor communication among Supervisors and management team at Adventist Health.

pros: Not many positive.  Sr. Leadership allows Managers to walk all over Directors.  They have gone through 5 Directors in as many hears. Hospital CEO uses rounding as an excuse to micromanage front line cutting Directors out of there leadership prerogatives and responsibilities.   Until this changes there is not much hope. here
cons: Many significant management problems mainly with Sr. Leadership in this area

job_title: Registered Nurse, Critical Care in Marysville, CA
pros: Small hospital, staff is like family, we all know one another or you at least say hello to everyone daily.  Great opportunities for learning and self-improvement. Able to advance up quickly, when ready.
cons: Because it's a small hospital, everyone feels your business is theirs and entitled to opinions about your choices. Lacks up to date equipment for patient care and charting. Short on staff frequently.

pros: Faith based environment, many departments are flexible with schedule times, compete time pay, fun work events, Friday worship service, wonderful mission and Adventist Health leaders are great.
cons: Not much of a training process in place for new hires, the company that they partner with for their software and managing the revenue cycle is horrible and the managers from that company are mostly horrible as well.

pros: Family Oriented Organization, Faith based
cons: It can be noted that promotions are more of who you know and are friends with then with qualifications.  They have hired way too many nurses from foreign countries and being able to communicate is very important however it is increasingly being reported that the nurses are difficult to understand and talk in their native language in front of others regularly.

pros: Several CNA ON EACH FLOOR PER SHIFT
cons: seniority means nothing here. I've been here 6 years and those that were hired after myself are being transferred to other departments. Or trained to be CnA2 or unit clerks or tele techs.  I am older and for dome reason I am never given the opportunity to transfer to another position.

pros: Some genuinely nice people. People out by 3pm on Fridays because of SDA practice. Opportunity to learn if you're willing because of lack of resources/people. If you're SDA, jackpot! You'll be fast-tracked to management regardless of performance.
cons: Some real shady creeps, rampant nepotism for SDAs. No investment into employees. Questionable business practices for "transformations" in finance, HR, etc. Bills weren't getting paid to vendors/landlords and employees pay was also messed up for months. Because pay is so low talent is bottom of the barrel types except for maybe a very bright 5-10%, don't think AH will survive in the next 10 years.

review_title: "The best place to work" is seriously true. We state it in our vision, but it is truly lived out. I love my job!
pros: Showing gratitude to employees for their hard work and years of service. Making employees opinion feel valued and feeling that you are important to the organization. The closeness we have with leadership, even at the executive level.
cons: I have yet to find a Con is the 2 plus years I've been working for Adventist Health/CVN.

review_title: Talented and caring team that fosters personal and professional growth.
pros: Very supportive team that encourages skill development and service excellence. Great opportunity for growth and transitions to more responsibility/higher compensation etc. Emphasis on constant improvement individually and as a team. Strong emphasis on mission that promotes consistent service excellence.
cons: Work-life balance can be a struggle because everyone works really hard and you don't want to be the weak link in the team. Constant change among programs and services, but that's consistent with all healthcare organizations these days.

pros:
They just instituted a minimum $15/hr wage for CMC.
Friendly staff
Caring for patients equals or bests that of other hospitals
free parking for employees (for now) and visitors.
Health and other benefits are good.
Clean and inviting design/deco is welcoming
Within Depts:
From the top down, strives to be the best in patient care. 
Connect page (IT) has everything an employee needs from looking up policy's to pay checks.
Very good work place policies in place.
cons:
There will always be Cons - no place is perfect. Look at what is behind the smiling faces.
-teamwork needs loads of work. Still hearing a lot of ...'that's not my job" comments
-Pt to CNA ratio improving but still needs work in other depts
-house keeping needs help with staffing competent workers, relying on a few experienced to carry the workload
-Pay needs to increase 
-lower morale in some departments, and complete dissatisfaction in others
-Directors and managers of departments who hide terrible infractions made by their 'friends' 

CMC is not alone. This is a world full of humans and yes we make mistakes, but you can't learn from them if you hide from your mistakes and are afraid of trying something/someone new.

pros: We really thrive and believe on our mission. Employees are all here for the right reasons. The staff are all very understanding and flexible to work around our personal life with children, great benefits and a very positive environment.
cons: I do feel if you're not "Adventist" or don't have a degree, there is no room for you to grow within the company.

review_title: Not a terrible place. I would work there again.
pros: Truly nice coworkers, kind of a small town thing. Direct supervisors (charge nurses) are pretty awesome as well.  OK pay for the area. Nurses really try and do their best to render excellent patient care.  They have a terrific new grad program and are linked in with the local junior college RN program, so all our green nurses are pretty good.  There is a healthy culture of learning and being able to ask "dumb questions." Also nurses here don't eat their young, like at some places.  I would recommend this as a generally good place to work.
cons: You can't advance too high  into management if you are not Seventh Day Adventist. Management does not really like "unit hoppers." If you have good ideas, but have been pegged as a "worker bee" good luck getting the leeway to implement your ideas or have them heard. The corporate office creates an "us and them" dynamic, that leads to top-down decisions being pushed through without any thought for the workers. There have been recent cuts in benefits disguised as "new choices." As with many med/surg RN jobs it seems thet each day its more charting, more charting, more charting, without regard to nurse workflow. Inbred long-term management.  AHSR is the only game in town, so if you don't like it too bad. Staffing levels are sometimes whacked, leading to falls. There seems to be a blame the nurse, not the system attitude from management when there is a problem, which is opposite from what we learned in nursing school.

pros: The staff members are very dedicated and kind
cons: If you do not belong to the Adventist Church, do not expect to advance or to have upper management treat you with respect.  Focus and goals change monthly and the ability to improve is negatively impacted by the company's lack of stable goals.

pros: Great coworkers, keep the day upbeat.  Quality care provider.  Willing to try new technology, on the leading edge, leads by example.  Best place to work, best place to practice medicine makes it the best place to receive care.
cons: Staying on the leading edge of technology can sometimes mean a rocky start with new systems.  Somewhat rural so when staffing is short it can take awhile to fill a position.

pros: Enjoy the employee culture here. Most staff are here to make a difference and understand the importance of working together to ensure success.
cons: Sometimes projects can be under-resourced due to lack of planning. This can turn into unrealistic deadlines that should have been set far in advance of their due date.

job_title: Certified Nursing Assistant/Ward Clerk in Lodi, CA
pros: Great place to work. Great staff all around! Everyone focuses on Patient Care and great customer service.
cons: I feel the hospital should allow nurses to work part-time if they choose. A lot of great nurses have gone to other hospitals and left a void. Although it does make room for new nurses. It's just very sad to watch great ones depart unnecessarily!

review_title: Best place I have ever worked
pros: Caring team members and management, great perks, good work life balance. People are kind. Big focus on becoming more progressive which means fun projects, very open to new ideas. Unlike other organizations people are authentic here and there aren’t political games.
cons: They are catching up in technology but they know it and are working to get there. Culture is a little old fashioned but they are trying to change that as well.

review_title: I really enjoy working here.  Everyone is very friendly and the hospital feels like one big family.
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Simi Valley, CA
pros: I think the thing that I like most is the people.  The people here are really nice.  Unlike bigger hospitals, it is common for executive staff to know your name and say hi to you in the cafeteria or hallways.  I feel valued and appreciated in my job.

review_title: It has it's ups and downs.
pros: Amazing work/family atmosphere on the departmental level.  Once you have your in with other departments and their leaders, there is a level of respect you gain from your peers.
cons: The Seventh Day Adventist atmosphere can be difficult at times and it really requires you to try harder than normal to move your way up.

pros: Adventist Medical Center is a fantastic place to work. Executive leadership is committed to both excellence in the care we provide to patients and to employee satisfaction. Additionally AMC seems to genuinely care about the physical, mental and spiritual health of employees.
cons: We're occasionally heavy on the meetings but I see leadership trying to fix that.

pros:
Are you a Seventh Day Adventist? Do you count on your church connections for employment and advancement? Do you believe that all you need are friends in high places and that knowing how to do your job doesn't matter? Does mind-numbing hypocrisy and a pay rate that is far below the average appeal to you? Then look no farther, you have found where you belong! 

All others, look elsewhere.
cons:
1. Pay rate is far below the average for IT positions.
2. Leadership positions are heavily biased towards church members. The organization recruits from Adventist academies, promising even high school students leadership positions. It is not unheard of for fresh from-college-with-no-work-experience-church-members (with high-ranking church family members) get Director level jobs immediately at Adventist Health.
3. No cost of living increases for rank and file employees. The only "merit" raise that is given is a yearly 2.5% step increase, maximum. However, check the IRS form 990's for Adventist Health... senior leadership gives themselves massive yearly raises, far above the state and national averages for healthcare senior leadership.
4. Putting AH leadership in a room with our main "partner", Cerner, is like putting guppies in a shark tank (AH are the guppies, Cerner is the shark. Turns out you mostly need to earn leadership at Cerner...there's a concept!). Cerner will continue to get whatever they want and give AH products that they don't need and aren't ready for release.
5. Benefits... what benefits? The medical benefits at this organization will cost you more and provide far less than their competitors.
6. Politics are out of control. This organization is very much a cult of personality. It is who you know, not what you know, that counts at AH for the most part. Many of the long-time employees have come to AH straight from an Adventist academy and never worked anywhere else, so have no idea of what the "real" world is like. 

I could go on and on, but I think all reading this will get the general drift. Please, if you have any talent and knowledge and other opportunities, do yourself a favor and find employment elsewhere. Maybe once AH realizes they aren't going to get and retain talented individuals unless they value ALL employees (and yes, AH, value also means paying them a competitive wage), things will improve. Only when that happens would I recommend this organization as a place to work for any non-Seventh Day Adventist.

review_title: Can't keep up with healthcare trends
pros: Some of the people are great, caring, and compassionate when it comes to patient care.  The hospital has won a few awards in this area.
cons:
Adventist Medical Center. It used to be good, but just has so many hurdles to overcome, I just don't feel they will be successful in the future of healthcare. 

Employees used to feel valued. This is slowly slipping away with increasing health plan premiums, unfair wages, and top heavy management. Employees also have very little resources when it comes to mobility. There is no clinical ladder, performance appraisals are a joke, and management write them based on the last two weeks of your work performance. The only way to move up is to be a relative of a member of management, or go to an Adventist church. 

They have created a very disjointed system. They utilize two application systems for care: Cerner systems within the hospital, and Epic within the 40 clinics they run. They have also partnered with Cerner to manage employees of Adventist in some departments. This creates a very awkward message to employees as well as patients, because both companies just don't have a mission that aligns with one another. 

They struggle with branding, and really entering a community they don't understand the demographic for. They currently only hold about 6% of the market for healthcare in the area. They just can't compete with the other large organizations who are well known for quality care. 

They have recently undergone a transformation to move several entities of administration to the corporate office located in Roseville California. They are changing the mission, investing in new HRIS systems, and shifting several things to make the entire organization run as one entity, instead of separate hospitals. Hopefully this change goes well, however they are still riddled with hardship during this process due to the amount of upper management. For example why would an organization have 19 CFO's? Shouldn't there only be one... at the corporate office? Is there really a need for a Director, Manager, and Supervisors, over each department, at each hospital? Hopefully this will be looked into later, and the new corporate structure will realize and eliminate redundant positions and invest more on the positions that provide quality care and community outreach. Adventist Medical Center is just so slow to make any changes, by the time they do it may be too late. I would love to see another organization (possibly OHSU) come in and take over (not just partner) because the location really is convenient for patients and employees on the East side of Portland. Would be a great place to work if it was more efficiently run.

pros: From my experience, it's worse at Dignity
cons:
Stay away from San Joaquin Community. Besides the usual bullying of nursing culture, this is one of the worst hospitals to work for in the state of California.

I’ve worked in other facilities prior to this and this is the only hospital where they are constantly short staffed. To be asked to work 16 hour shifts is the norm. They’ll either ask you to stay an extra 4 hours or come in 4 hours early. It doesn’t not matter whether or not you’ve already worked your 3 days or in the middle of it, if you don’t do it, you will be bullied.

The new grad program is horrible. The program is disorganized and the preceptors are unknowledgabe. My preceptor, who was a seasoned nurse, would ask other nurses including other new grads what to do when I asked her a question. Everyone is clueless.

The machines are outdated. Imagine having an RRT and calling a doctor who is already upset and has a strong accent, on a bad cell phone reception and your outdated spectra link is having it’s own issues. 

Computers keep freezing up. Especially during a med pass. The tube systems can break down from time to time. So you have to run across campus to get blood as necessary. 

We are one of the lowest paid facilities and it shows. Don’t’ believe me? Take a tour at one of our facilities. Don’t let the star bucks and valley parking fool you. 

There is no live interpreter. You have to use the phone, which I previously mentioned has issues, making communication almost impossible at times.

Arranging patient transport can be time consuming so typically nurses have to bring each of their patient down for CT, MRI, etc. 

You will be floated. It does not matter if you are a medsurg nurse, an ICU nurse, whatever. All nurses are floated to high acquity departments such as ICU and ER. The worse part is, the ER float offers no orientation. You will be taking care of ACTUAL ER PATIENTS and no one will help you. You may get lucky and get some help with other floats, but don’t expect it as the ER is very fast paced and has some of the worst bullies in the hospitals.
